title: CiteAnalyzer
text: CiteAnalyzer designed citation analysis Google Scholar data. addresses key common challenges face analyzing citation data, including: Rate limiting blocking prevention built-request throttling Comprehensive metrics calculation beyond basic h-index i10-index Multi-scholar comparison normalized ranking systems Collaboration network analysis identify research communities Temporal trend analysis track research impact time Publication impact visualization interactive plots Unlike existing tools, CiteAnalyzer ensures reproducibility, robust error handling, integration biological research workflows.

title: CiteAnalyzer
text: install CiteAnalyzer Bioconductor: install development version GitHub:
code: remotes::install_github("danymukesha/CiteAnalyzer")

title: CiteAnalyzer
text: primary function extracting Google Scholar data ExtractScholarData(). function includes built-rate limiting prevent Google Scholar blocking requests.
code: library(CiteAnalyzer)  # Extract data for a scholar (replace with actual Google Scholar ID) # For demonstration, we'll use a sample ID scholar_data <- ExtractScholarData("qc6CJjYAAAAJ", max_publications = 50,                                    cache_dir = "temp/")  # View basic information print(scholar_data@name) #> [1] "Albert Einstein" print(scholar_data@affiliation) #> [1] "Institute of Advanced Studies, Princeton" print(scholar_data@interests) #> [1] "Physics"

title: CiteAnalyzer
text: CiteAnalyzer provides metric calculation beyond standard indices:
code:
# Calculate all available metrics metrics <- GetScholarMetrics(scholar_data)  # View results print(metrics) #> $h_index #> [1] 50 #>  #> $i10_index #> [1] 50 #>  #> $m_index #> [1] 0.8935571 #>  #> $citations_per_paper #> [1] 5197.02  # Calculate specific metrics h_index <- calculate_h_index(scholar_data@publications$citedby) i10_index <- calculate_i10_index(scholar_data@publications$citedby) m_index <- calculate_m_index(     h_index,      min(scholar_data@publications$year, na.rm = TRUE) )  cat(sprintf("h-index: %d
i10-index: %d
m-index: %.2f
",             h_index, i10_index, m_index)) #> h-index: 50 #> i10-index: 50 #> m-index: 0.41

title: CiteAnalyzer
text: package provides several visualization functions help interpret citation data:
code: # Plot top publications by citations p1 <- PlotCitationImpact(scholar_data, plot_type = "summary") print(p1) # Plot publication and citation timeline p2 <- PlotCitationImpact(scholar_data, plot_type = "timeline") print(p2)

title: CiteAnalyzer
text: CiteAnalyzer excels comparing multiple scholars using normalized metrics:
code: # Extract data for multiple scholars scholar1 <- ExtractScholarData("qc6CJjYAAAAJ", max_publications = 30,                                 cache_dir = "temp") scholar2 <- ExtractScholarData("VWCHlwkAAAAJ", max_publications = 30,                                cache_dir = "temp") scholar3 <- ExtractScholarData("vzXv764AAAAJ", max_publications = 30,                                cache_dir = "temp")  # Compare scholars comparison <- CompareScholars(list(scholar1, scholar2, scholar3))  # View comparison results print(comparison) #>            scholar_id            name #> h_index  qc6CJjYAAAAJ Albert Einstein #> h_index1 VWCHlwkAAAAJ     Alan Turing #> h_index2 vzXv764AAAAJ Michael I. Love #>                                                               affiliation #> h_index                          Institute of Advanced Studies, Princeton #> h_index1                                 Reader, University of Manchester #> h_index2 Associate Professor, Genetics and Biostatistics, UNC-Chapel Hill #>          h_index i10_index citations_total publications_count h_index_rank #> h_index      129       380          189291                 50            1 #> h_index1      48       105           78841                 30            2 #> h_index2      42        88          124174                 30            3 #>          i10_index_rank citations_total_rank publications_count_rank #> h_index               1                    1                       1 #> h_index1              2                    3                       2 #> h_index2              3                    2                       2 #>          composite_score overall_rank #> h_index             1.00            1 #> h_index1            2.25            2 #> h_index2            2.50            3  # Create comparison visualization p3 <- PlotCitationImpact(scholar1, plot_type = "comparison",                          compare_with = list(scholar2, scholar3),                          radar_coord = "polar") print(p3)

title: CiteAnalyzer
text: Track citation patterns evolve time:
code: # Analyze trends for multiple scholars trends <- AnalyzeCitationTrends(list(scholar1, scholar2, scholar3), time_period = "10y")  # Plot publication trends p4 <- PlotPublicationTrends(list(scholar1, scholar2, scholar3), trend_type = "both") print(p4)

title: CiteAnalyzer
text: Identify potential research collaborators based similarity metrics:
code: # Find potential collaborators for scholar1 collaborators <- FindCollaborators(scholar1, list(scholar2, scholar3), min_similarity = 0.2)  # View results print(collaborators) #>    candidate_name candidate_id #> 1     Alan Turing VWCHlwkAAAAJ #> 2 Michael I. Love vzXv764AAAAJ #>                                              candidate_affiliation #> 1                                 Reader, University of Manchester #> 2 Associate Professor, Genetics and Biostatistics, UNC-Chapel Hill #>   interest_similarity h_index_similarity composite_similarity target_h_index #> 1                   0              0.800                0.240            129 #> 2                   0              0.773                0.232            129 #>   candidate_h_index #> 1                48 #> 2                42

title: CiteAnalyzer
text: Visualize collaboration networks researchers:
code: # Create citation network network <- CreateCitationNetwork(list(scholar1, scholar2, scholar3), min_citations = 5)  # Plot collaboration network if (igraph::gsize(network) > 0) {     p5 <- PlotCollaborationNetwork(network, layout_type = "fr")     print(p5) }

title: CiteAnalyzer
text: CiteAnalyzer provides toolkit citation analysis Google Scholar data. addressing key challenges like rate limiting, reproducibility, metric calculation, enables user gain deeper insights research impact collaboration patterns. implement structured S4 classes, extensive documentation, visualization capabilities make suitable individual users large-scale bibliometric studies. Future versions include integration additional citation databases sophisticated network analysis algorithms.

title: Addressing Research Challenges
text: package includes built-rate limiting retry mechanisms prevent Google Scholar blocking requests:
code: # The ExtractScholarData function automatically handles: # - Rate limiting between requests # - Retry attempts on failures # - User agent rotation # - Request timeouts

title: Addressing Research Challenges
text: analysis functions return structured S4 objects can saved shared:
code: # Save scholar data for reproducibility saveRDS(scholar_data, "scholar_analysis.rds")  # Load later for consistent results loaded_data <- readRDS("scholar_analysis.rds")

title: Addressing Research Challenges
text: Beyond standard metrics, CiteAnalyzer provides: - m-index (normalized h-index career years) - Citation per paper ratios - Field-weighted citation impact estimates - Journal impact factor estimation

title: Addressing Research Challenges
text: package uses Bioconductor S4 classes integrates Bioconductor packages:
code: # Works with BiocParallel for large-scale analysis # library(BiocParallel) # results <- bplapply(scholar_ids, function(id) { #     ExtractScholarData(id, max_publications = 20) # })

title: Addressing Research Challenges
code: sessionInfo()

title: Best Practices
text: Even built-rate limiting, considerate making requests:
code: # Good practice: Add additional delays between scholar extractions scholar_ids <- c("id1", "id2", "id3") results <- list()  for (id in scholar_ids) {     results[[id]] <- ExtractScholarData(id, max_publications = 20)     Sys.sleep(10)  # Additional delay between scholars }

title: Best Practices
text: Cache results avoid repeated requests:
code: # Check if cached data exists cache_file <- "scholar_cache.rds" if (file.exists(cache_file)) {     cached_data <- readRDS(cache_file) } else {     # Extract and cache data     cached_data <- ExtractScholarData("qc6CJjYAAAAJ", max_publications = 50)     saveRDS(cached_data, cache_file) }

title: Best Practices
text: Use try-catch blocks robust analysis:
code: safe_extract <- function(scholar_id) {     tryCatch({         ExtractScholarData(scholar_id, max_publications = 20)     }, error = function(e) {         warning(sprintf("Failed to extract data for %s: %s", scholar_id,                          e$message))         NULL     }) }

title: Best Practices
code: sessionInfo()

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
text: Toolkit analyzing citation data Google Scholar. Provides data extraction rate limiting, citation metrics, collaboration network analysis, publication impact visualization. Addresses common challenges including Google Scholar blocking, data reproducibility, multi-scholar comparison.

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
text: Key Features Installation Quick Start Analysis Documentation

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
text: Built-rate limiting adaptive delays Automatic retry mechanisms exponential backoff User-agent rotation prevent IP blocking Request timeout handling graceful recovery

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
text: Standard metrics: h-index, i10-index, m-index Advanced metrics: field-weighted citation impact, citations per paper Temporal analysis: 5-year 10-year trend comparisons Journal impact factor estimation citation patterns

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
text: Co-citation network generation publication data Research community detection using clustering algorithms Interactive network visualization customizable layouts Potential collaborator identification based research interests

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
text: Publication citation timeline analysis Multi-scholar comparison normalized ranking Interactive plots exploring citation patterns Publication-quality visualizations ready manuscripts

text: S4 class system structured data storage Complete analysis pipelines single function calls Data caching export capabilities Integration Bioconductor parallel processing

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
code: if (!require("remotes", quietly = TRUE))     install.packages("remotes")  remotes::install_github("danymukesha/CiteAnalyzer")

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
code: # Clone repository git clone https://github.com/danymukesha/CiteAnalyzer.git cd CiteAnalyzer  # Build and install R CMD build . R CMD INSTALL CiteAnalyzer_1.0.0.tar.gz

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
code:
library(CiteAnalyzer)  # Extract data for a scholar (using example ID - replace with actual ID) # Example ID: "qc6CJjYAAAAJ" - replace with your target scholar's ID scholar_data <- ExtractScholarData("qc6CJjYAAAAJ", max_publications = 20)  # View basic information about the scholar cat("Name:", scholar_data@name, "
") cat("Affiliation:", scholar_data@affiliation, "
") cat("Research Interests:", scholar_data@interests, "
") cat("Total Publications:", nrow(scholar_data@publications), "
") cat("Total Citations:", scholar_data@citations_total, "
") cat("h-index:", scholar_data@h_index, "
") cat("i10-index:", scholar_data@i10_index, "
")  # Plot top publications by citations PlotCitationImpact(scholar_data@, plot_type = "summary")  # Plot publication and citation trends over time PlotCitationImpact(scholar_data@profiles, plot_type = "timeline")

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
code: # Extract data for multiple scholars scholar1 <- ExtractScholarData("qc6CJjYAAAAJ", max_publications = 30) scholar2 <- ExtractScholarData("M4SrmDIAAAAJ", max_publications = 30)  scholar3 <- ExtractScholarData("9cHj9xMAAAAJ", max_publications = 30)  # Compare scholars comprehensively comparison_results <- CompareScholars(list(scholar1, scholar2, scholar3))  # View comparison table print(comparison_results)  # Create visualization comparing all three scholars PlotCitationImpact(scholar1, plot_type = "comparison",                    compare_with = list(scholar2, scholar3))

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
code: # Identify potential collaborators based on research similarity collaborators <- FindCollaborators(     target_scholar = scholar1,     candidate_scholars = list(scholar2, scholar3),     min_similarity = 0.25 )  # View ranked list of potential collaborators print(collaborators)  # Focus on top collaborator if (nrow(collaborators) > 0) {     top_collaborator <- collaborators$candidate_name[1]     cat(sprintf("Top potential collaborator: %s\n", top_collaborator)) }

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
code: # Analyze citation trends over different time periods trends_5y <- AnalyzeCitationTrends(     list(scholar1, scholar2, scholar3),     time_period = "5y" )  # Plot publication and citation trends PlotPublicationTrends(     list(scholar1, scholar2, scholar3),     trend_type = "both",     smoothing_span = 0.4 )

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
code: # Create and visualize collaboration network network <- CreateCitationNetwork(     list(scholar1, scholar2, scholar3),     min_citations = 5 )  # Plot the network with Fruchterman-Reingold layout if (igraph::gsize(network) > 0) {     PlotCollaborationNetwork(         network,         layout_type = "fr",         highlight_scholar = scholar1@scholar_id     ) }

title: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar
code: # Estimate journal impact factors from publication data journal_impact <- estimate_impact_factor(     scholar1@publications,     year_range = 5 )  # View top journals by estimated impact factor print(journal_impact)

title: CiteAnalyzer: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar — CiteAnalyzer-package
text: Toolkit analyzing citation data Google Scholar. Provides data extraction rate limiting, citation metrics, collaboration network analysis, publication impact visualization. Addresses common challenges including Google Scholar blocking, data reproducibility, multi-scholar comparison.

title: CiteAnalyzer: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar — CiteAnalyzer-package
text: Google Scholar Blocking Prevention: Built-rate limiting, automatic retries, user-agent rotation Comprehensive Metrics: Standard metrics (h-index, i10-index, m-index) plus advanced field-weighted impact scores Collaboration Networks: Co-citation network analysis research community detection Temporal Analysis: Publication citation trends time smoothing algorithms Multi-Scholar Comparison: Normalized ranking system fair comparison across disciplines Publication-Quality Visualizations: Interactive plots ready manuscripts presentations Bioconductor Integration: S4 classes, parallel processing support, reproducible workflows

title: CiteAnalyzer: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar — CiteAnalyzer-package
text: ExtractScholarData Extract comprehensive data Google Scholar profiles rate limiting ScholarProfile Create complete scholar profiles analyses one call CompareScholars Compare multiple scholars using normalized metrics composite scoring AnalyzeCitationTrends Analyze publication citation patterns time FindCollaborators Identify potential research collaborators based similarity metrics CreateCitationNetwork Generate co-citation networks publication data PlotCitationImpact Create publication-quality visualizations citation metrics PlotCollaborationNetwork Visualize research collaboration networks customizable layouts PlotPublicationTrends Plot publication citation trends smoothing

title: CiteAnalyzer: Citation Analysis from Google Scholar — CiteAnalyzer-package
text: ScholarProfile-class S4 class storing individual scholar data publications ScholarData-class S4 class storing comprehensive analysis results including networks trends

title: Extract Scholar Data from Google Scholar — ExtractScholarData

title: Extract Scholar Data from Google Scholar — ExtractScholarData
text: scholar_id Character string containing Google Scholar ID (e.g., "qc6CJjYAAAAJ") max_publications Integer maximum number publications retrieve (default: 100) rate_limit_seconds Numeric seconds wait requests (default: 5) retry_attempts Integer number retry attempts request fails (default: 3) user_agent Character string custom user agent (optional) cache_dir Directory storing cached data (default: NULL temporary cache)
